Bayar Rendah Pekerja Asing, Crust Pizza di Tasmania Didenda Rp 1 Miliar
04 Nov 2019, 03:45 by ABC
Semakin banyak perusahaan Australia dikenai denda karena membayar pekerja asing rendah sehingga melanggar peraturan yang ada di sini guna melindungi pekerja dari eksploitasi.
Diskriminasi Pembayaran Restoran Pizza

Empat pekerja yang waktu itu mahasiswa internasional bekerja di Crust Gourmet Pizza tahun 2016
Mereka dibayar upah $12 per jam dan $1 untuk mengantar pizza
Keseluruhannya, empat pekerja itu seharusnya mendapat bayaran tambahan $9,926 sesuai dengan upah minimum

Dalam kasus terbaru, pemilik restoran Crust Pizza di ibukota negara bagian Tasmania, Hobart telah dikenai denda $AUD 104 ribu (lebih dari Rp 10 miliar) karena membayar empat pekerja lebih kecil dibandingkan pekerja lain asal Australia.
Empat pekerja tersebut - tiga warga Bangladesh dan satu warga India - adalah mahasiswa internasional ketika mereka bekerja di franchise Crust Gourmet Pizza di Elizabeth Street , North Hobart antara bulan Januari sampai Juli 2016.
Tugas mereka ketika itu adalah membuat pizza, mengantar pizza, melayani pembeli dan juga bersih-bersih.
Mereka dibayar upah tetap $12 (sekitar Rp 120 ribu) per jam untuk kerja jam berapa saja, ditambah $1 (sekitar Rp 10 ribu) untuk mengantar pizza.
Upah minimum di Australia di tahun 2016 adalah $17.70 dan umumnya upah mengantar pizza per satu kali penghantaran adalah $3-$4.
Keempat pekerja juga dibayar tunai dan tidak mendapat slip upah, dan juga diminta mengantar pizza ke tempat yang lebih jauh dibandingkan pekerja asal Australia.
Selama mereka bekerja di sana, keempat pekerja tersebut seharusnya mendapat bayaran $AUD 9.926 lebih banyak dari apa yang mereka dapatkan.
Dibandingkan keempat pekerja tersebut, restoran Crust Pizza di North Hobart ini memberikan upah yang lebih tinggi kepada pekerja asal Australia dengan uang mereka langsung dibayarkan ke rekening bank.
Upah berbeda
Pemilik restoran tersebut, perusahaan bernama QHA Foods Pty Ltd dan dua direkturnya Anandh Kumarasamy dan Haridas Raghuram mengakui bahwa mereka sudah melanggar berbagai aturan.
Salah satu pelanggaran adalah melakukan diskriminasi terhadap pekerja berdasarkan latar belakang kebangsaan mereka.
Perusahaan tersebut dikenai denda $AUD 80 ribu (sekitar Rp 800 juta) dan Kumarasamy dan Raghuram â€” yang terlibat dalam pengelolaan restoran tersebut masing-masing dikenai denda tambahan masing=masing $12 ribu.
Menurut Fair Work Ombudsman, kedua pemilik restoran yang merupakan warga asal India sebenarnya tahu bahwa para pekerja mereka harus mendapat upah minimum namun sengaja membayar lebih rendah.
Dalam keputusannya, Hakim Federal Barbara Baker setuju adanya dua sistem pembayaran yaitu untuk pekerja Australiad dan satu lagi untuk pekerja internasional.
"Walau apa yang mereka kerjakan sama, ada perbedaan pembayaran bagi kedua kelompok tersebut." kata Hakim Baker dalam keputusannya.
Fair Work ombudsman Sandra Parker mengatakan para penyidik mereka mengetahui masalah ini setelah mendapat laporan dari seorang pekerja asing.
"Membedakan pembayaran bagi pekerja asing adalah hal yang tidak bisa diterima oleh kami maupun oleh pengadilan." kata Parker.
"Semua pekerja memiliki hak yang sama, tidak tergantung pada status visa mereka, dan kami menganjurkan siapa saja yang mereka diperlakukan tidak adil untuk menghubungi Fair Work Ombudsman." kata Parker lagi.

Low Paying Foreign Workers, Crust Pizza in Tasmania Fined Rp. 1 Billion
Nov 04 2019, 03:45 by ABC
More and more Australian companies are being fined for paying low foreign workers and violating the rules here to protect workers from exploitation.
Discrimination Payment for Pizza Restaurants

Four workers who were then international students worked at Crust Gourmet Pizza in 2016
They are paid a wage of $ 12 per hour and $ 1 to deliver pizza
In all, the four workers should have been paid an additional $ 9,926 according to the minimum wage

In the latest case, the owner of Crust Pizza restaurant in the capital of the state of Tasmania, Hobart has been fined $ AUD 104 thousand (more than Rp. 10 billion) for paying four workers less than other workers from Australia.
The four workers - three Bangladeshis and one Indian - were international students when they worked at the Crust Gourmet Pizza franchise on Elizabeth Street, North Hobart between January and July 2016.
Their job at that time was to make pizza, deliver pizza, serve customers and also clean.
They are paid a fixed wage of $ 12 (around Rp. 120 thousand) per hour for any hour of work, plus $ 1 (around Rp. 10 thousand) to deliver pizza.
The minimum wage in Australia in 2016 is $ 17.70 and generally the pizza delivery fee per delivery is $ 3- $ 4.
The four workers were also paid in cash and did not get a wage slip, and were also asked to take the pizza to a place farther than the Australian worker.
While they worked there, the four workers should have been paid $ AUD 9,926 more than what they got.
Compared to the four workers, the Crust Pizza restaurant in North Hobart provides higher wages to workers from Australia with their money directly paid into a bank account.
Wages are different
The restaurant owner, a company called QHA Foods Pty Ltd and two of its directors Anandh Kumarasamy and Haridas Raghuram admitted that they had broken various rules.
One violation is discrimination against workers based on their national background.
The company was fined $ AUD 80 thousand (around Rp 800 million) and Kumarasamy and Raghuram - who were involved in managing the restaurant were each subject to an additional $ 12 thousand each.
According to the Fair Work Ombudsman, the two restaurant owners who are Indian citizens actually know that their workers must get a minimum wage but deliberately pay lower.
In its decision, Federal Judge Barbara Baker agreed that there are two payment systems, namely for Australian workers and another for international workers.
"Despite what they do together, there are differences in payments for the two groups." said Judge Baker in his decision.
Fair Work Ombudsman Sandra Parker said their investigators were aware of the problem after receiving a report from a foreign worker.
"Distinguishing payments for foreign workers is something that cannot be accepted by us or the court." said Parker.
"All workers have the same rights, regardless of their visa status, and we encourage anyone they are treated unfairly to contact the Fair Work Ombudsman." Parker said again.
